turns.content: John keats poem called bright star

"Bright Star" is a sonnet written by John Keats in 1819. The poem is often considered one of Keats' most beautiful and expressive works, and is known for its themes of love, beauty, and the transience of life. The poem's speaker addresses a star, asking it to remain constant and unchanging, while the speaker's own life is filled with change and uncertainty. The poem concludes with the lines "Bright Star! would I were steadfast as thou art— / Not in lone splendour hung aloft the night, / And watching, with eternal lids apart, / Like nature's patient, sleepless Eremite, / The moving waters at their priestlike task / Of pure ablution round earth's human shores, / Or gazing on the new soft-fallen mask / Of snow upon the mountains and the moors— / No—yet still steadfast, still unchangeable, / Pillow'd upon my fair love's ripening breast, / To feel for ever its soft fall and swell, / Awake for ever in a sweet unrest, / Still, still to hear her tender-taken breath, / And so live ever—or else swoon to death."
Which kind of rhyme it is?

"Bright Star" is a sonnet, and specifically, it's a form of sonnet called "Shakespearean sonnet" which consist of 14 lines, and follows a specific rhyme scheme. The rhyme scheme of a Shakespearean sonnet is abab cdcd efef gg. Each quatrain (four-line stanza) follows the pattern of the rhyme scheme and the final couplet (two-line stanza) usually brings the poem to a conclusion or gives a final thought.
Which is the tone of the poetry?

The tone of John Keats' "Bright Star" is one of longing and yearning. The speaker of the poem expresses a deep desire to be as constant and unchanging as the star, while recognizing that his own life is filled with change and uncertainty. The speaker also expresses a sense of awe and reverence towards the star and nature. Additionally, there is a hint of melancholic and nostalgic throughout the poem, as the speaker speaks of the passing of time and the transience of life.
